page.title: 15COHAM HOUSE
page.content: The Coham family has been connected with Black Torrington since 1100. Coham House was first built then and rebuilt in 1700 and 1865. The present house is mainly Victorian. It stands in a wooded setting a kilometre north west of the village and belongs to Mr and Mrs Coham-Fleming. It contains several pictures and antiques, but many were burnt in a fire in 1978. The family coat of arms contains Arscott, Coham, Bickford and Holland symbols. Once many servants were employed but now there is only a housekeeper. The house is reputed to be haunted by the Blue Lady, who died after her brother was killed. The beautiful woods were planted 150 years ago, on the slopes between the house and the Torridge. Coham House is not open to the public, but Larks and Sparks are held annually on the Hams beside the river.
